translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Nāla and Māli
The Elder Ukkāsati
“The Fortunate One named Kosiya,
was dwelling on Cittakūṭa;
The Buddha, a meditator, one who delights in meditation,
the Sage, one who delights in solitude.
Having entered the Himalayas,
surrounded by a group of women;
I saw the Buddha Kosiya,
like the full moon.
Having taken a cough mixture,
I surrounded him then;
Having stayed for seven nights and days,
I went on the eighth day.
The Buddha Kosiya,
the self-dependent one, the undefeated one;
With a confident mind I worshipped him,
and gave him one alms-food.
By that deed, O Leader of Men,
the best in the world, the bull of a man;
I was reborn in the Tuṣita host,
this is the fruit of the one alms-food.
Day and night,
there is always light for me;
All around for a hundred leagues,
I shine with my radiance.
For fifty-five aeons,
I was a Wheel-turning Monarch;
I was a conqueror of the four corners (of the earth),
a lord over the Rose-Apple Island.
At that time my city was,
prosperous, thriving, and well-populated.
It was thirty leagues long
and twenty leagues wide.
The city called Sobha
was built by Vissakamma.
It was ten leagues in circumference
and surrounded by a wall of bricks.
In that city there was no
timber, clay, or bricks.
It was entirely made of gold
and always shone.
It was surrounded by four walls
made of three precious substances.
In the middle was a palm-leaf fence
built by Vissakamma.
Ten thousand lotus ponds🔽covered with blue and white lotuses
were filled with
various fragrances.

analyzed: catunnavutitaḥ kappe  yam ukkam dhārayim aha
translated: For ninety-four eons🔽I carried a torch.
I do not remember any bad destination
as a result of carrying the torch.
My defilements were burned up,
I live without defilements.
Welcome indeed it was for me
…🔽I have done what had to be done.
The four analytical knowledges,
I have done what had to be done.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā ukkāsatiko thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmai ukkāsatikaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus has the venerable Ukkāsatika told this verse.
The Story of the Elder Ukkāsatika is finished.
